I'm not surprised to see that the Lefties have failed to comment on the incident involving the Dave Matthews Band. For those who aren't aware, this uneducated buffoon leads the way on all sorts of whacked out environmental/Liberal issues, and yet his tour bus dumps a huge load of waste while crossing a bridge, a load that happens to land on a tourist boat beneath (of course, it'll be spun that it was a boatload of evil Conservatives that deserved it). They got the license plate of the bus, so he is guilty as charged. Any spinsters on the left care to comment on the hypocrisy...WITHOUT dragging in anything about the Right!

We are all guilty of hypocrisy at some level. One might need a SUV for an ambitious outdoor lifestyle and your equipment and loved ones need to be transported somehow. There are no free rides. The fact that better(less polluting) options are not available to people is really the result of a lack of vision and direction from our government(both parties). There are of course absolute limitations but incentives for new technology are woefully lacking. Going with existing technology will always be easier and cheaper for manufacturers. IMO that's where the government comes in. 
 
 I also believe we need to hold our trading partners to similar standards as we have in place since we have deemed them appropriate. If offshore production had to meet our environmental standards to export to us it would help with our ability to compete and it is the right thing to do for the people in developing countries. Dumping banned chemicals and allowing environmental destruction to facilitate cheap goods in the developing world is criminal and probably racist. 
 
 Regardless, this administration's record thus far on the environment has been shameful. Not just my opinion.

This administration has been consistently trying to undo gains under the former administration. My favorite is the proposed lifting of road building bans in many "wilderness" areas in this country. Taxpayers have always footed the bill for the "prospecting" of large companies be it lumber or minerals or oil. In many cases private concerns need only lease the land and the government pays to provide access to extract the resources. When no longer profitable the leasee simply walks away and the land is left to recover but rarely does in the true sense. These same roads are the single largest contributing factor to the degradation of watersheds and their biodiversity.

 The original question has been sidestepped by all the liberal/environmentalists. Someone needs to answer this directly and plainly.
 
 Are the facts that Dave Matthews champions the environmental cause and that he dumped doodoo in the river a sign that he doesn't really believe what he espouses?...that he doesn't practice what he preaches?...that he's a hypocrit?
 
 Yes or No?

 
 
 NO
 
 Everything living on earth goes poo poo. Eventually it comes back around. If I ate my own turds then, yes I'd get sick. But if i went doo doo in the river, I certainly wouldn't drink right after it, but wait a while (if the river was good to drink in the first place. Doo Doo is not pollution unless it's highly concentrated and starts killing things in the water/land where it's released.
 
 There is a big difference between dumping one toilet's worth of poo poo on some boat (or even in the river) and continuously dumping poo poo from thousands of people into a river, day after day.
 
 I figured you might have a fecal fetish, but...If you smear dog doo doo on anything of mine and I find out, you'll find your bedroom has become a place of highly concentrated doo doo that may even kill a goldfish or two.
 
 The way to determine if something can be considered a polluting event: Did it kill anything or disrupt an ecosystem? If the answer is yes, then it can be considered pollution. I doubt that Dave Matthews toilet water did these things.
 
 (ps- I can't stand Dave Matthew or his band, fyi.)

So why is it OK to smear it on everyone else's 'property'?
 Cleaning up after your dog isn't a environmental issue nor has ever been claimed to be, its a health and social issue.
 
 As for dumping a small amount of waste in a river, the rules are there to prevent damage from many people carrying out the same act - unless one person is directly responsible, in your senario nothing would change and the river would become as polluted as if they did.
